title: Performance Management
overview: Performance Management (20% of Part 1) is not just calculation—it is diagnostic analysis. It answers: Did we perform as expected? If not, why? Who is responsible? It covers the full spectrum from Variance Analysis (Static vs. Flexible budgets, Mix/Yield) to Responsibility Accounting (ROI, RI, EVA, Transfer Pricing) and non-financial measures (Balanced Scorecard, COQ). The goal is to align behavior with strategy, prevent suboptimization, and ensure long-term value creation.
bulletNotes: Flex Your Budget: Always compare Actual Results to a Flexible Budget (adjusted for actual volume), never the Static Budget.
Variance Hierarchy: Total Variance = Sales Volume Variance (Quantity) + Flexible Budget Variance (Price/Efficiency).
Material Price Variance is based on Quantity PURCHASED (Procurement responsibility); Usage on Quantity USED (Production responsibility).
Fixed Overhead Volume Variance is unique: It measures CAPACITY utilization (Over/Under absorption), not spending control.
ROI Trap: Managers may reject profitable projects (e.g., 15% return) if they lower their current high ROI (e.g., 20%). This is Suboptimization.
Residual Income (RI) Fix: Measures absolute $ value added above cost of capital. Aligns with shareholder value.
Transfer Pricing: Minimum Price = Variable Cost + Opportunity Cost (Lost Contribution Margin).
Balanced Scorecard: Adds Leading Indicators (Customer, Process, Learning) to Lagging Financial Indicators.
Cost of Quality: Investing in Conformance (Prevention/Appraisal) drastically reduces Non-Conformance (Failure) costs.
shortNotes: Think Economically: Favorable variances aren't always 'good' (e.g., cheap materials causing rework). Master the 'AQ x AP | AQ x SP | SQ x SP' column method. Understand that Performance Measures drive Behavior—be able to predict how a manager will act under ROI vs RI. Variance analysis is for control, not punishment.

concepts.title: 1. Philosophy & Budgeting Framework
concepts.content:
The Philosophy

Performance management answers: "Did we perform as expected? Why not? Who is responsible? What behavior will this encourage?" It is diagnostic analysis.

Static vs Flexible Budget (The Foundation)

Static Budget: Prepared at the start of the period based on planned output. Does NOT adjust. Used for planning.

Flexible Budget: Adjusted to the actual output level using standard costs per unit. Used for performance evaluation.

Why This Matters: If sales increase, total variable costs naturally increase. This is not 'poor performance'. We must compare Actual Results vs Flexible Budget to isolate efficiency.

concepts.title: 2. Variance Hierarchy & Sales Variances
concepts.content:
The Big Picture

Total Variance = Actual Results - Static Budget

Broken down into:

  1. Sales Volume Variance: (Flexible Budget - Static Budget). Difference due purely to quantity sold.
  2. Flexible Budget Variance: (Actual Results - Flexible Budget). Difference due to price, cost, or efficiency.

Sales Variances (Revenue Side)

Sales Price Variance: (Actual Price - Std Price) × Actual Qty Sold. Measures pricing power. Responsibility: Sales Mgr.

Sales Volume Variance: (Actual Qty - Std Qty) × Std Contribution Margin.
Crucial: Uses Contribution Margin, NOT Selling Price, because fixed costs don't change with volume.

concepts.title: 3. Direct Material & Labor Variances
concepts.content:
Direct Materials (Two-Way Split)

  • Price Variance (MPV): (AP - SP) × AQ Purchased.
    Trap: Use Qty PURCHASED. Purchasing Manager controls price at the point of buy.
  • Usage Variance (MUV): (AQ Used - SQ Allowed) × SP.
    SQ Allowed: Actual Output × Std Qty per Unit. Responsibility: Production Manager.

Direct Labor Variances

  • Rate Variance (LRV): (Actual Rate - Std Rate) × Actual Hours. Responsibility: HR/Hiring.
  • Efficiency Variance (LEV): (Actual Hours - Std Hours Allowed) × Std Rate. Responsibility: Production.

concepts.title: 4. Manufacturing Overhead Variances
concepts.content:
Variable Overhead

  • Spending Variance: (Actual Rate - Std Rate) × Actual Hours. Similar to Labor Rate variance.
  • Efficiency Variance: (Actual Hours - Std Hours) × Std Rate. Driven by the efficiency of the base (e.g., labor hours).

Fixed Overhead (4-Way Analysis)

  • Spending Variance: Actual Fixed Cost - Budgeted Fixed Cost. Measures over/under spending vs budget in dollars.
  • Volume Variance: Budgeted Fixed Cost - Applied Fixed Cost.
    Applied = Std Hours × Fixed Rate.
    This variance exists because fixed costs are allocated based on standard capacity. If Actual Output < Budgeted Capacity, we have Under-absorption (Unfavorable Volume Variance). It measures Capacity Utilization.

concepts.title: 5. Advanced Variance Analysis
concepts.content:
The 3-Column Method (Best for Exam)

Actual (AQ × AP)Flexible (AQ × SP)Standard (SQ × SP)
Real costs incurredInput for Price VarianceTarget cost for output
← Price/Rate Variance →← Usage/Efficiency Variance →

Trade-Offs & Interpretation

Economic View: A Favorable variance isn't always good. Example: Buying cheap material (Favorable Price Var) causes scrap (Unfavorable Usage Var) and rework (Unfavorable Efficiency Var). Always analyze the Net Impact.

When to Investigate: If variance is Material, Recurring, Controllable, or Strategic.

Mix & Yield Variances (Advanced)

  • Sales Mix Variance: Impact of selling a different proportion of high-margin vs low-margin products.
  • Sales Quantity Variance: Impact of total volume difference involved.

concepts.title: 6. Responsibility Accounting (ROI vs RI)
concepts.content:
Responsibility Centers

  • Cost Center: Costs only (Maintenance).
  • Revenue Center: Revenue only (Sales).
  • Profit Center: Both (Product Line).
  • Investment Center: Revenue, Costs, Assets (Subsidiary). Evaluated via ROI/RI.

Return on Investment (ROI)

ROI = Income / Invested Capital

DuPont Analysis: (Income/Sales) × (Sales/Assets) = Margin × Turnover.

The Trap: Managers reject project with 15% return if current ROI is 20%, even if Cost of Capital is 10%. This is Suboptimization.

Residual Income (RI)

RI = Operating Income - (Invested Capital × Required Rate)

The Fix: Measures dollar value created. If RI is positive, value is added. Solves underinvestment problem.

Economic Value Added (EVA)

Refined RI using NOPAT and WACC. EVA = NOPAT - (Capital × WACC).

concepts.title: 7. Transfer Pricing
concepts.content:
Purpose

Goal congruence, Autonomy, Performance evaluation, Tax planning.

General Rule

Minimum Transfer Price = Variable Cost + Opportunity Cost

  • Excess Capacity: Opp Cost = 0. Min Price = Variable Cost.
  • Full Capacity: Opp Cost = Lost Contribution Margin. Min Price = Market Price.

Methods

  • Market-Based: Best for autonomy/congruence if market exists.
  • Cost-Based: Variable or Full Cost. (Full cost can pass on inefficiencies).
  • Negotiated: Can cause conflict.

concepts.title: 8. Balanced Scorecard & Quality
concepts.content:
Balanced Scorecard (BSC)

Links strategy to operations via 4 perspectives:

  1. Financial: "How do we look to shareholders?" (ROI, EPS, EVA). Lagging.
  2. Customer: "How do customers see us?" (Market share, Retention).
  3. Internal Process: "What must we excel at?" (Cycle time, Defect rate).
  4. Learning & Growth: "Can we continue to improve?" (Training, IT systems). Leading.

Strategy Map: Learning → Process → Customer → Financial.

Cost of Quality (COQ)

  • Conformance (Good Quality): Prevention (Design, Training) + Appraisal (Testing, Audits).
  • Non-Conformance (Bad Quality): Internal Failure (Scrap, Rework) + External Failure (Warranty, Brand damage).

Insight: Spending on Prevention is cheaper than paying for Failure.

concepts.title: 9. Behavioral & Advanced Issues
concepts.content:
Behavioral Implications

  • Suboptimization: Division maximizes own results at company expense (common with ROI).
  • Short-Termism: Cutting R&D or Maintenance to boost quarterly income.
  • Gaming: Accelerating sales or delaying maintenance.

Goal Congruence

The system must align managers' personal incentives with the company's best interests. RI and EVA are generally better than ROI for this.

Common Exam Traps

  • Using Budgeted Hours instead of Standard Hours Allowed for efficiency variances.
  • Confusing Fixed overhead Spending (Cost control) vs Volume (Capacity utilization).
  • Forgetting Sales Volume uses Contribution Margin.
  • Classifying Inspection as Prevention (it is Appraisal).

formulas.name: Sales Volume Variance
formulas.formula: (Actual Sold - Budgeted Sold) × Std Contribution Margin

formulas.name: Material Price Variance
formulas.formula: (Actual Price - Std Price) × Actual Qty Purcased

formulas.name: Material Usage Variance
formulas.formula: (Actual Qty Used - Std Qty Allowed) × Std Price

formulas.name: Labor Efficiency Variance
formulas.formula: (Actual Hours - Std Hours Allowed) × Std Rate

formulas.name: Fixed OH Spending Var
formulas.formula: Actual Fixed Cost - Budgeted Fixed Cost

formulas.name: Fixed OH Volume Var
formulas.formula: Budgeted Fixed Cost - (Std Hours × Fixed Rate)

mistakes: Using Budgeted Hours for efficiency variances (Must use Standard Hours Allowed for Actual Output).
Using Quantity Used for Price Variance (Must use Quantity Purchased).
Thinking Favorable Variance = Good Performance (Could be low quality).
Confusing Fixed OH Volume Variance with Spending (Volume is about capacity).
Ignoring Opportunity Cost in Transfer Pricing when at full capacity.
Rejecting a positive-NPV project because it lowers division ROI.

quiz.question: Which of the following best describes the 'Minimum Transfer Price' when the selling division has excess capacity?
quiz.explanation: With excess capacity, there is no opportunity cost (no lost sales). Thus, the minimum price is simply the Variable Cost.

quiz.question: A favorable Direct Material Price Variance coupled with an unfavorable Direct Material Usage Variance most likely indicates:
quiz.explanation: Buying cheap materials (Favorable Price) often leads to waste/scrap (Unfavorable Usage). This is a classic trade-off.

quiz.question: Why is Residual Income (RI) often preferred over Return on Investment (ROI) for performance evaluation?
options: It is a percentage, making comparison easier
It eliminates the suboptimization problem of underinvestment
It focuses solely on gross margin
It ignores the cost of capital
quiz.explanation: RI encourages managers to accept ANY project that earns more than the cost of capital, whereas ROI leads managers to reject profitable projects that might lower their average ROI.

quiz.question: Which of the four Balanced Scorecard perspectives is considered a 'Leading Indicator'?
quiz.explanation: Learning & Growth (training, systems) drives improvement in Process, which drives Customer, which drives Financial results. It is the foundation.

quiz.question: Fixed Overhead Volume Variance determines the difference between:
options: Actual Fixed Costs and Budgeted Fixed Costs
Budgeted Fixed Costs and Applied Fixed Costs
Actual Fixed Costs and Applied Fixed Costs
quiz.explanation: Volume Variance = Budgeted Fixed Overhead - Applied Fixed Overhead. It measures whether the company produced enough volume to validly 'absorb' the fixed costs.

essay.question: Evaluate the behavioral implications of using ROI as the sole performance metric for an investment center manager. Start by defining ROI, then discuss at least two specific dysfunctional behaviors it might encourage, and propose an alternative metric that could mitigate these issues.
essay.modelAnswer:
1. Definition: ROI (Return on Investment) = Operating Income / Invested Capital. It measures the return generated per dollar of investment.

2. Dysfunctional Behaviors:

  • Underinvestment (Suboptimization): A manager with a high current ROI (e.g., 20%) may reject a profitable project yielding 15% (above the company's 10% cost of capital) because it would mathematically lower their average 20% ROI. This hurts the company's total value.
  • Short-Termism: Managers may cut R&D, maintenance, or training costs to boost the numerator (Income) or delay asset purchases to reduce the denominator (Invested Capital), harming long-term viability.

3. Alternative Metric: Residual Income (RI) or EVA. RI = Income - (Capital × Cost of Capital). Since RI measures absolute dollar value added, the manager in the example above would accept the 15% project because it generates positive RI, aligning personal incentives with company shareholders.

summary: Performance Management (20%) is the diagnostic heart of Part 1. It requires moving beyond calculation to interpretation. Mastery involves understanding the 'Why' behind variances (Trade-offs), the 'Who' behind responsibility (Centers), and the 'How' of motivation (ROI vs RI). Success here means thinking like a CFO, not just a calculator.
